required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Predicting Individual Response to Analgesic Treatment in Painful Diabetic Neuropathy

brief_summary.textblock: Diabetic nerve pain [painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy] is a common medical problem with few reliably effective treatments. There is some evidence that sensory testing may help determine how individuals will respond to analgesic therapy. In this study, the investigators are evaluating the relationship between sensory testing and subject response to lidocaine infusion therapy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Diabetic peripheral neuropathy [DPN] is caused by diabetes-related metabolic damage to the sensory nervous system. It affects more than 3 million Americans and is leading cause of nerve damage-associated pain worldwide. Currently approved drugs such as gabapentin, pregabalin, and duloxetine provide pain relief only in 1 out of 4 or 5 people with DPN, pointing to a great need to identify effective therapy for these patients. Recent literature suggests that certain methods of assessing sensory nerve function in neuropathic pain patients may provide prediction to individual analgesic response; however, no placebo-controlled studies have been performed with the primary goal of identifying treatment response predictors in DPN.
We propose in this study to examine whether sensory testing to determine mechanical pain threshold [MPT] or heat pain threshold [HPT] will predict the subject's response to IV lidocaine analgesic therapy. We hypothesize that people with painful DPN who have high MPT or HPT are more likely to respond to lidocaine treatment. This is a prospective, double blind, placebo-controlled study with the primary objective of determining whether the results from the sensory testing predict the response to systemic lidocaine in patients with painful DPN.
Consented subjects will attend a screening visit and two intervention visits, during which they will undergo sensory testing and receive intravenous lidocaine or placebo infusion in a cross-over design. At enrollment, each patient will be assigned a study number, which will match a previously prepared computer-generated list of randomization numbers to determine the sequence of interventions: lidocaine and then placebo, or vice versa. An unblinded research nurse coordinator will be assigned to match the study number with randomized treatment sequence, and this person will prepare the study medications, which will look identical. This research nurse coordinator will not be involved at any stage at patient assessment or data analysis. The participants and all other study personnel will be blinded to the treatment allocation.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Spontaneous Pain at 60-120 Minutes After Lidocaine Infusion Initiated (Assessed on 0-10 NRS)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline compared to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
primary_outcome.description: Spontaneous pain will be assessed on numerical rating scale NRS (0= no pain, 10=worst pain imaginable) prior to infusion and then repeatedly for 120 minutes. The outcome measure will use the average of pain intensity measured at timepoints in the 60-120 min range after beginning of infusion. The mean %change in pain (from baseline) will be compared between lidocaine and placebo arms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evoked Mechanical and Thermal Sensation at Baseline and 60 Minutes After Infusion Initiation.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: - 60 minutes (baseline) and + 60 minutes of initiating infusion
secondary_outcome.description: Thermal and mechanical responses will be assessed at baseline and 60 minutes after infusions. Evoked intensities measured on a 0-10 sensory scale, where 5 is normal sensation, a number lower than 5 is reduced sensation and a number higher than 5 is greater sensation.

secondary_outcome.measure: NPSI (Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory) Descriptors of Pain at Baseline and 60 Min After Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to 60 minutes of initiating infusion
secondary_outcome.description: NPSI pain descriptors will be assessed prior to infusion of placebo and lidocaine (baseline) and again at 60 minutes post-infusion. Descriptors are expressed on a 0-10 scale; 0-minimum (least), and 10 maximum (worst) score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Spontaneous Pain Intensity as a Function of Baseline MPT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between Mechanical Pain Threshold (MPT in mN) at baseline and reduction in spontaneous pain intensity (% reduction on 0-10 NRS) at 60-120 minutes (averaged) from the study drug infusion. The slopes (Pearson coefficients) of the correlation obtained from lidocaine vs. placebo will be compared.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Spontaneous Pain Intensity as a Function of Baseline HPT
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between Heat Pain Threshold (HPT in degrees Celsius) at baseline and reduction in spontaneous pain intensity (% reduction on 0-10 NRS) at 60-120 minutes (averaged) from the study drug infusion. The slopes (Pearson coefficients) of the correlation obtained from lidocaine vs. placebo will be compared.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Normal saline infusion then lidocaine infusion
arm_group.description: Intravenous infusion of normal saline over a 40 minute period. second intervention: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine [5mg/kg] over a 40 minute period.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Lidocaine infusion, then normal saline infusion
arm_group.description: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine [5mg/kg] over a 40 minute period. second intervention: Intravenous infusion of normal saline over a 40 minute period.

intervention.description: lidocaine is a sodium channel blocker/analgesic. It is approved for intravenous administration for cardiac arrhythmias.
intervention.arm_group_label: Lidocaine infusion, then normal saline infusion
Normal saline infusion then lidocaine infusion

intervention.description: Normal saline, approved for hypovolemia, and homeostasis.
intervention.arm_group_label: Lidocaine infusion, then normal saline infusion
Normal saline infusion then lidocaine infusion

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: One participant only received lidocaine infusion and did not return to receive saline infusion.

group.title: Saline First, Then Lidocaine
group.description: Intravenous infusion of normal saline (placebo) over a 40 minute period (Period 1). Intravenous infusion of lidocaine 5mg/kg IBW over a 40 min period (Period 2)

group.title: Lidocaine First, Then Saline
group.description: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine 5mg/kg IBW over a 40 min period (Period 1). Intravenous infusion of normal saline (placebo) over a 40 minute period (Period 2).

participants_list.participants: One participant did not return for Period 2 treatment

group.title: Saline First, Then Lidocaine
group.description: Intravenous infusion of normal saline (placebo) over a 40 minute period (Period 1). Intravenous infusion of lidocaine 5mg/kg IBW over a 40 min period (Period 2)

group.title: Lidocaine First, Then Saline
group.description: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine 5mg/kg IBW over a 40 min period (Period 1). Intravenous infusion of normal saline (placebo) over a 40 minute period (Period 2).

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Average pain intensity within the past week
measure.description: Average pain within the past week at study intake, assessed on a 0-10 Numerical Rating Scale, where 0 is no pain, and 10 is worst pain imaginable

outcome.title: Change in Spontaneous Pain at 60-120 Minutes After Lidocaine Infusion Initiated (Assessed on 0-10 NRS)
outcome.description: Spontaneous pain will be assessed on numerical rating scale NRS (0= no pain, 10=worst pain imaginable) prior to infusion and then repeatedly for 120 minutes. The outcome measure will use the average of pain intensity measured at timepoints in the 60-120 min range after beginning of infusion. The mean %change in pain (from baseline) will be compared between lidocaine and placebo arms.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline compared to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
outcome.population: Participants who completed both infusions and had non-zero pain scores at the start of each infusion.

group.title: Normal Saline Infusion
group.description: Intravenous infusion of normal saline over a 40 minute period. Placebo: Normal saline, approved for hypovolemia, and homeostasis.

group.title: Lidocaine Infusion
group.description: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine [5mg/kg] over a 40 minute period. lidocaine: lidocaine is a sodium channel blocker/analgesic. It is approved for intravenous administration for cardiac arrhythmias.

measure.title: Change in Spontaneous Pain at 60-120 Minutes After Lidocaine Infusion Initiated (Assessed on 0-10 NRS)
measure.description: Spontaneous pain will be assessed on numerical rating scale NRS (0= no pain, 10=worst pain imaginable) prior to infusion and then repeatedly for 120 minutes. The outcome measure will use the average of pain intensity measured at timepoints in the 60-120 min range after beginning of infusion. The mean %change in pain (from baseline) will be compared between lidocaine and placebo arms.
measure.population: Participants who completed both infusions and had non-zero pain scores at the start of each infusion.
measure.units: percentage of pain change from baseline

outcome.title: Evoked Mechanical and Thermal Sensation at Baseline and 60 Minutes After Infusion Initiation.
outcome.description: Thermal and mechanical responses will be assessed at baseline and 60 minutes after infusions. Evoked intensities measured on a 0-10 sensory scale, where 5 is normal sensation, a number lower than 5 is reduced sensation and a number higher than 5 is greater sensation.
outcome.time_frame: - 60 minutes (baseline) and + 60 minutes of initiating infusion
outcome.population: Participants who received both lidocaine and normal saline infusions were analyzed.

class.title: Does your pain feel like burning?
Does your pain feel like squeezing?
Does your pain feel like electric shocks?
Does your pain feel like stabbing?
Do you feel pins and needles?

outcome.title: Change in Spontaneous Pain Intensity as a Function of Baseline MPT
outcome.description: Correlation between Mechanical Pain Threshold (MPT in mN) at baseline and reduction in spontaneous pain intensity (% reduction on 0-10 NRS) at 60-120 minutes (averaged) from the study drug infusion. The slopes (Pearson coefficients) of the correlation obtained from lidocaine vs. placebo will be compared.
outcome.time_frame: baseline to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
outcome.population: Participants who completed both infusions and had non-zero pain scores at the start of each infusion.

group.description: Intravenous infusion of normal saline over a 40 minute period.

group.description: Intravenous infusion of lidocaine [5mg/kg] over a 40 minute period.

measure.title: Change in Spontaneous Pain Intensity as a Function of Baseline MPT
measure.description: Correlation between Mechanical Pain Threshold (MPT in mN) at baseline and reduction in spontaneous pain intensity (% reduction on 0-10 NRS) at 60-120 minutes (averaged) from the study drug infusion. The slopes (Pearson coefficients) of the correlation obtained from lidocaine vs. placebo will be compared.
measure.population: Participants who completed both infusions and had non-zero pain scores at the start of each infusion.

outcome.title: Change in Spontaneous Pain Intensity as a Function of Baseline HPT
outcome.description: Correlation between Heat Pain Threshold (HPT in degrees Celsius) at baseline and reduction in spontaneous pain intensity (% reduction on 0-10 NRS) at 60-120 minutes (averaged) from the study drug infusion. The slopes (Pearson coefficients) of the correlation obtained from lidocaine vs. placebo will be compared.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to 60-120 minutes after starting the infusion
outcome.population: Participants who completed both infusions and had non-zero pain scores at the start of each infusion. Two additional participants excluded as they could not sense heat on test site.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
